question: What two core technologies does gRPC primarily use for high performance?
How are messages and services defined in a gRPC application?
answers: Using a Protocol Buffer definition file (.proto)

question: What is a major advantage of defining an API in a .proto file?
answers: It only works for the Go programming language.
It allows for generating client and server code in multiple supported languages from a single definition.
It is human-readable like plain text, making it easy to debug.
It is tightly coupled with the implementation.

question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four supported API communication types in gRPC?
In the gRPC vs REST comparison table, how is the payload of gRPC described?
What type of gRPC API is most similar to a traditional REST API call?
What is the benefit of Protobuf's binary payload format?
answers: It is easy for humans to read and modify on the wire.
It leads to lightweight messages and high performance.
It is natively supported by all web browsers without any libraries.
It is less secure than text-based formats.

question: How does Protobuf handle backward compatibility when new parameters are added to a message?
answers: It requires all clients and servers to update simultaneously.
Old clients will crash when receiving a message with new parameters.
New parameters will not affect old clients, which will simply ignore them.
It automatically converts new parameters to a format the old client understands.

question: In the sample .proto file, what does 'rpc Sum(SumRequest) returns (SumResponse) {}' define?
answers: A remote procedure named 'Sum' within the 'CalculatorService'
A package for the protocol buffers
A variable to hold the sum
